results.title: In the company of men
results.creator_credit: Neil LaBute, Stephen Pevner, Mark Archer, Fair and Square Productions and Atlantis Entertainment
results.brief_description: This lacerating black comedy is an acerbic commentary on modern day masculinity. Two businessmen, sent by their company to oversee new company offices in another city, undertake a scheme to enact revenge on contemporary women. They plan to find a woman, wine and dine her, seduce her and then cruelly dump her. From this initial premise Neil Labute crafts an exceptionally taut and challenging work which explores the misogyny, racism and selfishness that underlies the competitive ethos of the new yuppie capitalist culture. Aaron Eckhart gives an outstanding performance as Chad, who imbues his vile character with a disturbing attractiveness. He is ably supported by Matt Malloy as his best friend who allows his personal morality and ethics to be subsumed by his desire to be “one of the boys”; and by Stacy Edwards as the “victim” who the men choose to abuse. Filmed in long takes which allow the actors to take centre stage, featuring excellent production design and music, “In the Company of Men” packs a mighty emotional punch. The end suggests that the culture of misogyny engendered by modern corporatism is as destructive on men as it is on women.

results.title: Raining stones
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Sally Hibbin, Film Four International and Parallax Pictures
results.brief_description: Set on a council estate in Middleton on the outskirts of Manchester, “Raining Stones” is an uncompromising look at England’s poorest citizens in a country where unemployment has created an alienated underclass and bred petty crime, vandalism, drug abuse and poverty. Already barely making ends meet, Bob supports his family by doing odd jobs. When his only asset, his van, is stolen, the family’s prospects become even grimmer. Now unemployed he is still determined to find the money to buy a new communion dress for his daughter’s first communion - even if it means turning to crime. Without ever mentioning politics, Loach makes a powerful and effective political statement about the way economic policies destroy social coherence. (Awards: Winner of the Special Jury Prize, Cannes Film Festival, 1993)

results.title: Thirty two short films about Glenn Gould
results.creator_credit: Francois Girard, Niv Fichman and Rhombus Media
results.brief_description: Thirty two short films about Glenn Gould is an inventive and playful film that seeks to portray the genius, complex and eccentric personality of legendary pianist, Glenn Gould. The film borrows its structure from JS Bach’s Goldberg Variations (and name from Beethoven’s “32 variations in C Minor”), and juxtaposes 32 short vignettes to portray the broadly influenced Gould. The film uses a combination of interview, dramatisation and animation, punctuated with the music of Gould’s live performances (mostly Bach, Beethoven and Shoenberg) to humorously fill the portrait of Gould. Included is an excerpt from Norman McLaren’s experimental animation ‘Spheres’ and Gould’s live radio broadcast of 28th December 1967, ‘The Idea of North’. Peppered throughout are Gould’s philosophical ruminations such as, “for every hour you spend with people you need x more hours on your own”.

results.title: The Last temptation of Christ [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Cineplex Odeon and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: A controversial and challenging film of Jesus Christ’s life. Based on the novel by Nikos Kazantzakis, this Christ is an anguished, vain, sensual man battling the forces of both good and evil. The film traces the conflicts that lead to his final disavowal of the flesh in favour of the life of the son of God. Scorsese had for years tried to film the Kazantzakis’ novel and on its release it was met with great debate and fury. The film, however, is deeply spiritual. With Willem Dafoe as Jesus, Barbara Hershey as Mary Magdalene, Harvey Keitel as Judas, and an impressive cameo by David Bowie as Pontius Pilate. Music by Peter Gabriel.

results.title: La Bamba
results.creator_credit: Luis Valdez, Taylor Hackford, New Visions Pictures and Columbia
results.brief_description: Musical biography of Ritchie Valens, a poor Mexican-American who became a rock’n’roll sensation at age 17 in the 1950’s. Lou Diamond Phillips portrays Valens whose musical career ended when he was killed in the plane crash that also claimed the life of Buddy Holly. The music of Valens is performed by Los Lobos on the soundtrack.

results.title: Jericho
results.creator_credit: Thornton Freeland, Walter Futter and Buckingham
results.brief_description: In France 1917, heroic corporal Jericho Jackson accidently kills his abusive seargent. He is charged with the murder but escapes from military prison leaving his friend Captain Mack behind to face a five year prison sentence after being accused of assisting his escape. When Captain Mack is released in 1922, he vows to track down and capture Jericho who has by this time has made a home for himself in North Africa, practicing medicine and uniting the disparate Arab tribes on the annual salt caravan. When Mack finally confronts Jericho, has difficulty destroying the life he has built. Stars Paul Robeson, Henry Wilcoxon, Wallace Ford, John Laurie, Princess Kouka. Paul Robeson sings several songs including ‘Brother are you going my way?’.

results.title: Kikujiro
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Takio Yoshida, Masayuki Mori, Nippon Herald Films, Bandai Visual Company and Office Kitano
results.brief_description: Kikujiro, a lazy small time gangster, agrees to take a lonely boy who lives with his grandmother on a road trip during the summer holidays. The two set off to find the boy’s mother who he has never met. Over the course of the return journey the pair meet up with a range of eccentric characters who engage in a series of absurd games and exchanges. While Kitano’s deadpan comic character with a tendency to extreme and sudden violence is familiar from his earlier work, ‘Kikujiro’ marks a departure from the milieu of the criminal underworld to focus on the unlikely bond that gradually develops between the man and boy. The film evokes Chaplin’s ‘The Kid’, both in Kitano’s trademark use of visual gags and in its sentimental bittersweet tone. In Japanese with English subtitles. Cast includes Takeshi Kitano, Yusuke Sekiguchi and Kayoko Kishimoto.

results.title: The Love letter
results.creator_credit: Peter Ho-sun Chan, Kate Capshaw, Midge Sanford, Sarah Pillsbury and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: The lives of residents of Loblolly by the Sea are transformed by the discovery of a passionate love letter, written to and from a nameless person. Divorcee Helen McFarquar (Kate Capshaw), first to read the letter begins a steamy romance with the much younger Johnny (Tom Everett Scott) who helps out in the bookstore where she works. The awakening of dormant feelings questions her to re-assess her relationship to George (Tom Selleck), an old friend from the past who has always been in love with her but lacks the eloquence and poetry of the letter. As the letter changes hands to Helen’s friend and co worker (Ellen DeGeneres), the local policeman, it alters their lives and those around them indelibly, and as Helen’s distant mother arrives back to Loblolly from overseas she discovers they have more in common than she realised. Cast also includes Blythe Danner and Geraldine McEwan. Based upon the novel by Cathleen Schine.

results.title: Mr and Mrs Smith
results.brief_description: A Hitchcock movie with a difference, a romantic comedy. Successful New York couple David and Anne Smith live happily by mutually agreed rules, that is until their secrecy is shattered by a visit from the civil celebrant who married them some years earlier in Anne’s home town. He has arrived to tell them that due to a state boundary dispute at the time of their wedding, they are not legally married. Social conventions of the time require them to take up separate residences immediately as they reconsider whether they really wish to be married or whether their futures lie better apart.

results.title: The Agony and the ecstasy
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on Irving Stone’s mammoth bestseller, “The Agony and the Ecstasy” is the dynamic retelling of one of the fiercest and most productive collaborations in art history, that of artist and painter Michelangelo, and the man who commissioned him to paint the Sistine Chapel, Pope Julius II. As played by Charlton Heston (as the painter) and Rex Harrison (as the Pope), the men are both titanic egoists determined to leave eternity a unique vision of their love and faith for God. Though “the Agony and the Ecstasy” betrays an earlier era’s reluctance to deal with either Michelangelo’s ambivalent sexuality, or the Pope’s lustful material excesses, the emotionally violent duels between the men betray the deep extremes of hatred, jealousy and love which dominated their relationship. For a contemporary viewer it is the richly colourful cinematography and the epic reconstruction of Renaissance Rome which is the film’s long-lasting legacy. If the melodrama of the clashes between the tortured artist and the meglomaniac Pope now seem almost camp, the recreation of the feat of painting the vast Chapel still seems wondrous. Cast also includes Diane Cilento, Harry Andrews and Alberto Lupo.
